ETYMOLOGY: Probably a frequentative form of 'drip', or from a Germanic root similar to Old English 'drusian' (to fall, droop).
SINCE: Late 15th century (as verb), early 16th century (as noun)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: v.intr.: A verb that does not take a direct object.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To rain lightly in very fine drops.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: It started to drizzle this morning, so I took an umbrella.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 今天早上开始下蒙蒙细雨，所以我带了把伞。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: n.: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Light rain falling in very fine drops.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The drizzle was so light I barely noticed it.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 毛毛雨很小，我几乎没注意到。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: v.tr.: A verb that takes a direct object.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To pour a thin stream of liquid over something, especially food.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Drizzle some olive oil over the salad before serving.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 上菜前，在沙拉上淋点橄榄油。
